Package aips.search.informed

Class BestFirstSearchProblem

java.lang.Object
aips.search.SearchProblem
aips.search.informed.BestFirstSearchProblem
public abstract class BestFirstSearchProblem
extends SearchProblem
This class models a best-first search problem. To create your own specialised problem of informed search, extend this class. You still need to supply the evaluation function which is necessary for best-first search. The heuristic function is only needed if your evaluation function uses one.
Author:
K. Hui

  • Field Details

    • goalState

      public State goalState
      Most informed searches need to compute the distance between the current state and the goal. So I am storing the goal state into this attribute. You can always refer to this attribute and check if you have reached the goal state. Note that this attribute is only defined in the BestFirstSearchProblem class but not in its SearchProblem superclass.

  • Constructor Details

    • BestFirstSearchProblem

      public BestFirstSearchProblem​(State start, State goal)
      Construct a BestFirstSearchProblem object. Note that BestFirstSearchProblem is an abstract class. So you will not directly create a BestFirstSearchProblem object but from one of its concrete subclasses. This constructor is expected to be invoked from a concrete subclass.
      Parameters:
      start - The initial state.
      goal - The goal state.

  • Method Details

    • search

      public Path search()
      This is a specialised version of search tailored for informed search. It takes care of repeating states. If there are multiple paths to reach a certain state, it chooses the one with the lower cost. The initial and goal states should be defined when the BestFirstSearchProblem object is * created. This method simply starts the search. For debugging purpose, it prints a message for every 1000 nodes explored.
      Overrides:
      search in class SearchProblem
      Returns:
      The path to the goal. Or null if there is no solution.

    • evaluation

      public abstract double evaluation​(Node node)
      This evaluation function tells us how promising a Node is. It should return a lower score for a more promising Node. This must be tailored for a domain and supplied in a concrete subclass. Note that in best-first search, only the evaluation function f(n) is necessary. Not all best-first searches use a heuristic function h(n). In this method, you can use the Node.getCost() method to get the cost of the path up to the node. If you need a heuristic function, you can declare it in the BestFirstSearchProblem class and invoke it from your evaluation function.
      Parameters:
      node - The node to consider. You will be mainly looking at the State contains in the Node.
      Returns:
      The score of the node. The lower the score is, the better the node.
